abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Telecommunications and
            Information Communications Technology (ICT) Development
            Project for Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS)
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            coordination of a regional project is complex and stretches
            very thinly in terms of both project management and
            supervision resources. Five set of Ministers of
            Communications, and Prime Ministers, NTRCs and ECTEL
            (National Telecommunication Regulatory Commission and
            Eastern Caribbean Telecommunications Authority) were
            involved at critical junctures in project implementation.
            Even with the best intentions, the coordination to obtain
            signatures from all member countries on any change such as
            category reallocation or extension of the closing dates was
            a hard task. As a suggestion for future regional projects,
            resources to be deployed to project coordination will
            require to be full-fledged defined. A consideration for
            other ICT project in small countries it that it could be
            beneficial to share the fixed costs of ICT development and
            policy and regulation projects. Normal practice worldwide is
            for telecommunications policy and regulatory issues to be
            addressed on a national basis. A regional approach was seen
            as viable since the telecommunications issues facing each
            island were similar. A useful tool that could help future
            projects in countries with little experience in World Bank
            competitive bidding processes is the organization of
            business outreach workshops that provide with the knowledge
            to service providers. These workshops were found
            particularly helpful when dealing with ICT procurement processes.
